moves.1. Nf3:
I like playing Nf3 because it has three important merits which I like:
1- it is flexible ... not committing myself to any pawn structure
2- directly gain two squares in the center d4 and e5
3- allows a faster king-side castling
moves.1... Nc6: I guess my opponent likes flexibility too
moves.2. d4: pushing a pawn to the center, clearing the way for the dark-squared bishop and threatening d5 which if not taken care of, will make the knight make an exhausting journey.
moves.2... e6: defending d5 and clearing the way for the dark-squared bishop
moves.3. e4: gaining a two-pawns center ... I think the center will be mine
moves.4... g6:
want to fianchetto the dark-bishop. It is not a bad move. But, I don't like it because black needs to remove my two center pawns before he can make use of the long dark diagonal ... which will require time
and also this move weakens the f7 pawn a little
moves.5. c4: attacking a center pawn from side ... this move also allows my queen access to the queen side
moves.6. Nc3: developing and adding more forces to guard the center
moves.6... f6: want to clear the way for the bishop to use the long diagonal
moves.7. cxd5: eating from side and attacking the knight
moves.8... Nxf6: re-take with development and guarding the center ... I think black achieved his plan of activating the dark-bishop
moves.9. Be2: developing and clearing the way for castling
moves.9... Bf5: developing and putting the light-bishop on a good diagonal
moves.10... Qe7: clearing his back-rank and not committing himself to a specific type of castling
moves.11. Bg5: developing the dark-bishop and pinning the knight
moves.11... O-O-O:
castling queen-side. now, everything is clear and I should come up with a plan.

mmm ... let's try to weaken blacks pawn structure on the queen-side
moves.12. Bb5: want to exchange and weaken his pawn structure
moves.13... Nc6: I think instead of moving his knight, black should have moved his queen or d-rook to a place where a pawn-structure preserving re-take is possible.
moves.14... bxc6 15. Qa4: directly benefiting from the bad pawn structure and attack the isolated a7 pawn
moves.16. Rfe1: gaining the e file with tempo
moves.17. Ne5: moving the knight to an excellent outpost and threatening Nf7 forking the queen and the two rooks
moves.17... Rhf8: protecting against the fork ... I still have the initiative
moves.18. Rac1: moving the rook to an important half open file
moves.18... Rde8: trying to regain the e file
moves.19. Re3: I want to move the rook so I can double my rooks either on the c or e file
moves.19... Bd7: want to make a cheap discovery on my queen with c5 and winning the very important d4 pawn
moves.20. Nxd7: disallowing the discovery and deprive him from the bishop-pair
moves.20... Nxd7:
re-take ... I have the initiative

mmm ... what to do now; no comprehensive plans is coming to my head :-(
moves.21. Qb3+: let's check to keep the initiative
moves.21... Ka8 22. Rce1: doubling my rooks and threatening to win a rook ... note that my d4 pawn is hanging and nothing protects him but the "initiative"
moves.22... Rxe3: exchange what to do to protect the d4 pawn ...
moves.23. fxe3: re-take with the pawn to preserve material ... but, this gives him the very important f file :-(
moves.23... c5: This is a mistake as it lefts the d5 pawn hanging
moves.24. Bf4: closing the f file before taking the d5 pawn
moves.25... Qxd5 26. Nxd5: an exchange in my favor. as I am better to go to the endgame ahead in material and having a better pawn structure and also having the initiative as I am attacking the c7 pawn
moves.27. dxc5: taking the pawn ... notice that black cannot take b2 with the bishop as this will pin the bishop
moves.28. Rc1: attacking the knight and keeping the initiative
moves.29. b4: attacking the pinned knight forcing an exchange that is in my favor as I am more prepared to go to the end game
moves.30. Rxc5+: re-take with a check that preserve me the initiative
moves.30... Ke6 31. Rxc7: taking another pawn and preserving the initiative by attacking the g7 bishop
moves.31... Rf7:
perfect ... another exchange. 

endgame is mine
moves.32. Rxf7 Kxf7 33. Kf2: I am ahead in material having a passed pawn e3 ... I believe If made no mistake I will win this one and increase my rating
moves.33... Ke6: a battle will start now between the two kings to centerialize
moves.38... Kd7: nothing to do ... stepping back further
moves.40. Ba7 Kb7 41. Bc5: do you want to exchange and give me another passed pawn
moves.42... Kc7 43. Ke6: putting the king in front of pawn to clear the way for him
moves.44. a4 Ba3 45. Bd6+: step away because I want to promote
moves.46. Kd7:
And now black resigns as there is nothing stopping my pawn from promotion. this game was decided by a single tiny mistake.

If black did make use of the f-file I opened for him I would've lost badly ... I want to say thanks to roland75 it was a very good game ;-)
